This is my first ever game review after being on steam for 10+ years. Hopefully that carries some weight to what I say.

Lobbies are small, but that's just because people haven't figured out how fun this game actually is. The best BR out there. I hope more people are willing to try the game so the player base can grow. I personally do not have an issue with the smaller lobbies. I played when lobbies were full at 60 players as well as when lobbies were no more than 3 people. Both situations are fun, just different vibes. Less people means for free looting in the early mid game and usually leads to more explosive final circles with 2-3 max geared players duking it out. I think its very fun.

IMO the game is worth $15, but for the vast majority of people this will probably prevent them from trying the game which is super unfortunate because this is actually a very, very fun BR.

I received the game for free since I have been playing in every beta / early access that has been released, but I think the game is so worth it I willingly buy it for my friends so they can try it too and help grow the player base.
best battle royale game ever created, and to see its return delights me

negative.review:
SUPER PEOPLE is a great game in terms of concept, visuals, and character variety. The gameplay is fun, intense, and has the potential to stand alongside the biggest battle royale titles.
However, there‚Äôs a major issue that heavily affects the experience, especially for players in Europe and the Middle East.
The servers are too far away, causing "high ping" and "noticeable input delay", which gives opponents a huge advantage. Sometimes it even feels like the enemy is hacking, but in reality, it‚Äôs just the lag caused by the distant servers.

I sincerely hope the developers can add servers closer to these regions or improve connection performance, because the game truly deserves a larger, fairer player base.

For now, I don‚Äôt recommend players from Europe or the Middle East to play until the server issue is addressed, as the experience can be very frustrating despite how good the game itself is.

I can't speak for everyone but I know a lot of people will agree. Super People has the potential to be one of the biggest BR's out there. Especially in the current state of gaming. The game itself deserves an **8‚Äì9/10**, but the **developers‚Äô decisions are a -99/10**.

I honestly can‚Äôt understand why the devs keep sabotaging their own game.

1. They **killed the original version** by shutting it down for months! What did they expect? That players would just wait around? People move on.
2. Then they **came back branding it as SP2**. Seriously? SP1 wasn‚Äôt even properly launched yet, and now it‚Äôs already ‚Äú2‚Äù?
3. Now they‚Äôre **relaunching it as the ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù again**, but making **new players pay for it** ‚Äî what a genius move for a game that *relies on having more players*!
4. Oh and ofcourse! The region lock TPP and FPP mode! Another way to lessen the players... GENIUS!

Honestly, to fix things, **whoever is making these decisions needs to be removed from that role** ‚Äî or from the team entirely. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs one person or a few, but whoever they are, they‚Äôre dragging this project down.

Bring in a **strong marketing or sales strategist**, or better yet, **sell the game to someone capable of turning it around**.

[b]Super People is the ultimate case study in how to speedrun the death of your own game.[/b]

The core? Genuinely fun. The map is great, classes are unique, and the gunplay isn‚Äôt half bad. For a fleeting moment you‚Äôll think [i]‚Äúwow, this could actually be good.‚Äù[/i] Then the developers step in and remind you that no good thing is allowed to live.  

They split the playerbase like it‚Äôs their religion: ranked vs casual, FPP vs TPP, solo vs squads ‚Äî anything to make sure you never find a healthy lobby.
 
They slapped a [b]$22AUD paywall[/b] on a game that already failed for free. Bold strategy, Cotton.

They promised to ‚Äúbring back the original game‚Äù‚Ä¶ then wasted time shoving in [b]zombies and monsters[/b] that nobody wanted. Sure, they‚Äôre gone now ‚Äî but all it did was waste dev time and probably scramble the codebase into the bug-ridden mess we have today.

Servers? Hope you enjoy desync so bad you‚Äôll swear you hit every shot ‚Äî until the post-match screen tells you none landed. But what do you expect when the only available server is in Korea.

Bugs? Every update is like opening a Kinder Surprise ‚Äî except the surprise is that they haven‚Äôt fixed a single one.

They‚Äôre desperately throwing in [b]events and grindy item unlocks[/b] to keep the last few players engaged, like bailing water out of a sinking ship with a teaspoon.

They just rolled out Ranked mode before even the sweatiest players could reach level 20 to play it. Genius.

And of course, the store is back, stuffed with [b]loot boxes and gacha[/b] like it‚Äôs a mobile casino.  

This game could be great, it's so close, but the developers seem to lack the ability to make obvious decisions. Its genuinely a mystery that they were able to make a game this good after seeing how its been handled once given to players. Super People is the only game where you can actually feel the developers‚Äô obsession with self-destruction. It‚Äôs not just mismanagement ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-blown fetish for killing their own game.

The servers are too far away, causing "high ping" and "noticeable input delay", which gives opponents a huge advantage. Sometimes it even feels like the enemy is hacking, but in reality, it‚Äôs just the lag caused by the distant servers.

I sincerely hope the developers can add servers closer to these regions or improve connection performance, because the game truly deserves a larger, fairer player base.

For now, I don‚Äôt recommend players from Europe or the Middle East to play until the server issue is addressed, as the experience can be very frustrating despite how good the game itself is.

When Super People first launched, it was a surprisingly solid alternative to PUBG. It ran well, looked great, and the core gunplay felt satisfying. For a brief moment, it really seemed like it could carve out its own place in whatever is left of the BR genre.

But, as often happens with free-to-play models, the influx of cheaters quickly overwhelmed the experience for me. The developers‚Äô balance changes were lackluster, progression lost any meaningful weight, and the renaming to Super People 2 felt like the beginning of the end. Sure enough, by 2023 the game was officially terminated.

Now two years later: I played the Closed Beta Test after the game was renamed back to Super People. The promises were familiar‚Äîbetter anti-cheat (BattleEye lmao), improved balance, and new ways to attract players to what was already a dead-on-arrival relaunch. And now, they‚Äôve announced a move to a paid model, with legacy players exempt.

Do I think anything will actually change? Absolutely not. If they had simply made a clean PUBG-style clone; without the unnecessary classes and other frivolous mechanics - the game "could" thrive. It looks good, it plays well, but it‚Äôs weighed down by design decisions that nobody really asked for; if you're looking for that og BR itch then play PUBG, if you're wanting classes and abilities - play Apex.

Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game at this moment with everything that I've experienced thus far. I truly wish this game the best. As i wish there was truly an alternative to PUBG; as its really no better.

First of all, I want to make it clear that I‚Äôve been playing Super People since the very first alpha and then the first CBT‚Ä¶ and yet I had to buy the game (which supposedly was going to be free if you had already tested all the Super People releases like CBT 1 and 2, SP2, SP with zombies, and now this one). I ended up paying 8 dollars for it.

That being said, let‚Äôs continue: I don‚Äôt know what went through the developers‚Äô heads to turn a free game into a paid one without even fixing the most common issues (actually, I do know ‚Äî the devs are incompetent and money laundering, which is why we have this mess now).

I‚Äôm from Argentina, so logically I should be playing on a Brazil or Chile server, right? Well, wrong. I have to play in North America because the geniuses behind the game decided to only add 3 servers (NA, EU, and Asia). That means I‚Äôm forced to play with 140 ping, which is EXTREMELY UNPLEASANT.

And while we‚Äôre at it, the servers are horrible and a disaster. Every single error you can imagine in a battle royale/FPS is here. Bad connection? Yes. Poor hit registration? Yes. Items not spawning on the ground after parachuting because the server is overloaded and can‚Äôt generate them? Yes. ‚ÄúNetwork latency detected‚Äù messages every 20 seconds as if that‚Äôs normal? Yes. Teammates unable to enter the lobby because of a server connection issue? Yes. Seriously, search for 5 minutes and you‚Äôll find all of these bugs.

Then the gameplay is AWFUL. This is nothing like the original CBT. They removed weapon specializations, removed character perks, and now you have to buy them in a shop (and by the way, everything is obtained in that shop with the gold you farm ‚Äî but not attachments, of course). The weapons are unbalanced, causing either one-shots or turning into laser beams. Now everyone gets their ultimate in less than 30 seconds, which makes fights completely unbalanced and survival impossible. They removed the power bars and added altars that are even worse, with bugged effects. Character abilities don‚Äôt even work properly.

In summary, people, don‚Äôt buy this game. Let it die and don‚Äôt give money to a company that only wants to drain our wallets and treat us like idiots. I did it, I was an idiot ‚Äî but I‚Äôm saving you from making the same mistake. Go buy another game you‚Äôll actually enjoy.

This game is extremely disappointing. The graphics and optimization are terrible, the sound design is inconsistent, and even the most basic features like footsteps are poorly made. Don't bother paying for this game. It's clearly a cash grab using a game build from 4 years ago without addressing any of the issues (Edit: They've since made this free to play). It's a terrible example of a battle royale. If you played this around 4 years ago, it's the exact same game, complete with the same old bugs.

* No OCE servers still (years after they promised they would). Instead we are forced to play on Korean servers where the ping is 150 and feels like 600, resulting in being shot around cover over and over.
* The same bugs from 4 years ago are still ruining the game (can't cancel actions, can't loot a box, can't complete an armour upgrade)
* Too many classes just cover the features of cheating - fast running, see through walls, go invisible. Easy to prevent cheats when you incorporate it into the game itself. 
* The promise of being able to play for free if you've played before was rubbish. Their support page is highly confusing and you get no response. 
* The audio is AWFUL. Worst i've experienced in years of gaming. Too often you just don't hear footsteps, even for classes without the perk.
* When you can hear footsteps or a loot box that pings, you can't tell if it's above or below you. The directional audio (up and down) is non-existent.
* The game is horribly unbalanced. Some max level guns do far less damage than a basic ground gun.
* The classes make things so much worse. There's way too many of them and a handful are STILL way overpowered, all this time later. They didn't bother to review their data to see if the game is balanced. It's not. You go into a game where 12+ players (so every squad) have selected the same 3 classes because they're so OP.

I could go on, but I think you get the idea. This could be a great game if they took the time to address the issues. The fact they've asked for money for a game that hasn't been touched shows they're grabbing cash (edit: It's now FTP). Don't expect it to be live for much longer.

The game itself deserves an **8‚Äì9/10**, but the **developers‚Äô decisions are a -99/10**.

I honestly can‚Äôt understand why the devs keep sabotaging their own game.

1. They **killed the original version** by shutting it down for months! What did they expect? That players would just wait around? People move on.
2. Then they **came back branding it as SP2**. Seriously? SP1 wasn‚Äôt even properly launched yet, and now it‚Äôs already ‚Äú2‚Äù?
3. Now they‚Äôre **relaunching it as the ‚Äúoriginal‚Äù again**, but making **new players pay for it** ‚Äî what a genius move for a game that *relies on having more players*!
4. Oh and ofcourse! The region lock TPP and FPP mode! Another way to lessen the players... GENIUS!

Honestly, to fix things, **whoever is making these decisions needs to be removed from that role** ‚Äî or from the team entirely. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs one person or a few, but whoever they are, they‚Äôre dragging this project down.

Bring in a **strong marketing or sales strategist**, or better yet, **sell the game to someone capable of turning it around**.

But yeah I will recommend it because I want it to be successful!

[b]Super People is the ultimate case study in how to speedrun the death of your own game.[/b]

The core? Genuinely fun. The map is great, classes are unique, and the gunplay isn‚Äôt half bad. For a fleeting moment you‚Äôll think [i]‚Äúwow, this could actually be good.‚Äù[/i] Then the developers step in and remind you that no good thing is allowed to live.  

They split the playerbase like it‚Äôs their religion: ranked vs casual, FPP vs TPP, solo vs squads ‚Äî anything to make sure you never find a healthy lobby.
 
They slapped a [b]$22AUD paywall[/b] on a game that already failed for free. Bold strategy, Cotton.

They promised to ‚Äúbring back the original game‚Äù‚Ä¶ then wasted time shoving in [b]zombies and monsters[/b] that nobody wanted. Sure, they‚Äôre gone now ‚Äî but all it did was waste dev time and probably scramble the codebase into the bug-ridden mess we have today.

Servers? Hope you enjoy desync so bad you‚Äôll swear you hit every shot ‚Äî until the post-match screen tells you none landed. But what do you expect when the only available server is in Korea.

Bugs? Every update is like opening a Kinder Surprise ‚Äî except the surprise is that they haven‚Äôt fixed a single one.

They‚Äôre desperately throwing in [b]events and grindy item unlocks[/b] to keep the last few players engaged, like bailing water out of a sinking ship with a teaspoon.

They just rolled out Ranked mode before even the sweatiest players could reach level 20 to play it. Genius.

And of course, the store is back, stuffed with [b]loot boxes and gacha[/b] like it‚Äôs a mobile casino.  

This game could be great, it's so close, but the developers seem to lack the ability to make obvious decisions. Its genuinely a mystery that they were able to make a game this good after seeing how its been handled once given to players. Super People is the only game where you can actually feel the developers‚Äô obsession with self-destruction. It‚Äôs not just mismanagement ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-blown fetish for killing their own game.

UPDATE: Make sure to nominate Super People for the 'Labor of Love Award' in this years Steam Awards
